all_paragraphs: In a recent blog post, I posed a relatively simple sounding question — why is linear algebra taught so badly?

It generated a more passionate response than I’d expected. Many of the comments shared my frustrations — linear algebra text books and courses were, it seemed, characterised by a total lack of intuition, and an almost deliberate opaqueness. To demonstrate this, I set a question: what is the determinant of the following matrix?
We all agreed that the answer is 2, due to the following formula:
But why? And for that matter, what even is the determinant?

To get started, let’s get ourselves back into a linear transformation mindset. Recall from the previous blog that any matrix can be thought of a linear transformation. In particular, for a 2x2 matrix, the columns of that matrix tell us what happens to the basis vectors [1,0] and [0,1], respectively known as î and ĵ.

For example, by taking the columns of a the matrix [[2,0],[2,2]], we can look at what happens to î and ĵ, and from this we can see that the linear transformation that it represents is a horizontal rightward shear, followed by a scaling of factor 2.

Remember — what happens to the unit vectors during a linear transformation necessarily defines what happens to every point in the whole 2D plane. If we apply the above transformation to any 2D vector v = [x, y], that vector will end up at a new position given by x lots of ‘transformed î’ plus y lots of ‘transformed ĵ’. So even though transformations can be nicely defined in terms of the unit vectors, we should also think about the transformation having some effect on the whole space.
But is there a way that we can somehow quantify the effect of a transformation at this ‘spatial’ level? Consider the following transformations:

What happens to the area of the plane under these transformations? We can see that a rotation leaves area unaffected, but what about the scale and the shear? We know that the 2D plane goes on forever, and thus has infinite area. But we can clearly see from the green and pink gridlines that some squashing is taking place in these cases — the infinite space is ‘getting smaller’ (though, of course, it remains infinitely large).

This is clearly a bit of a mind trip, so let’s go back to our trusty unit vectors î and ĵ. Consider the area of the square formed by the unit vectors, where the top and bottom are given by î and the sides are given by ĵ.

Clearly this square has area 1, since the unit vectors each have length 1. Let’s now consider the transformation represented by the matrix [[2,0],[2,2]]. Again, let’s draw out what happens to î and ĵ, and in addition, what happens to that square.

We can see that the square stretches into a parallelogram (a square, of course, being a special type of parallelogram to begin with). We know that the area of this shape is given by the height, multiplied by the base length, which in this case is 2*2 = 4.

It’s worth noting that because of the ‘rules’ of linear transformations (parallel lines remain parallel, an equal distance between parallel lines is maintained, and the origin remains at the origin), we can apply the same transformation on any shape in the 2D plane, not just the square formed by î and ĵ, and its area would also increase by a factor of 4.
Can we generalise this thinking? Suppose we have a linear transformation represented by the following matrix:

Then by what factor will this transformation increase the area of a shape on the 2D plane? We can answer this question by working out the area of the parallelogram formed by transformed î and transformed ĵ.
To do this, we can perform some geometric trickery, as follows:

So we see that the linear transformation represented by the matrix [[a,b],[c,d]] will increase the area of a shape on the 2D plane by a factor of ad-bc. And if that formula looks familiar, then that’s because it should:
In fact, generally speaking, that’s exactly what the determinant is — the factor by which space is expanded by a given linear transformation.

Now, although this is very nice and neat, it isn’t quite the whole story. If you’ve worked with determinants before, you’ll know that they can be negative — there’s certainly nothing about the formula ad-bc that precludes negative values. But what does it mean for this space expansion factor to be negative? You can’t exactly have a shape with an area less than zero.
Let’s see if we can try to work out what’s going on. Consider the following pairs of transformed î and transformed ĵ, and their respective determinants:
We’ve held transformed î (in blue) constant. As we’ve moved transformed ĵ closer, we can see that the determinant gets smaller, until ĵ eventually moves ‘past’ î and the determinant becomes negative.

In fact, this ‘flipping’ of î and ĵ is precisely what determines whether or not a determinant is negative or positive. Indeed, whether or not space has been ‘flipped’ is another aspect the transformation that we can immediately learn from the determinant.

There is another special case related to the above — the case when the determinant is zero. Indeed, the main motivation when learning all of this is often to check when a matrix is ‘zero-determinant’ or not. But what does such a matrix do in terms of linear transformations, and what are the consequences of this?
Consider the parallelogram formed by transformed î and transformed ĵ. We’ve shown that the determinant is given by this shape’s area, so in what cases could this be equal to zero?

Well, for this shape to have zero area, we’d need the base or the height to equal zero. This happens in a couple of trivial cases (i.e. when [a, c] = [0, 0], or [b, d] = [0, 0], but it also happens when transformed î and transformed ĵ are parallel to each other. This can happen when they’re lying on top of each other, or they’re exactly opposite each other.

Those of you with some pre-existing linear algebra knowledge can be more precise; in particular, we have a zero area parallelogram (and hence a zero-determinant matrix) when transformed î and transformed ĵ (i.e. the columns of the matrix) are linearly dependent.

This has important consenquences if we think about what’s happening in terms of linear transformations — namely the degree to which a transformation ‘squashes’ the 2D plane. If transformed î and transformed ĵ are linearly dependent, then, by definition, all of the linear combinations of transformed î and transformed ĵ are restricted to a single line. In essence, we lose a dimension; 2D space gets squashed onto a single 1D line.

Without an intuitive grounding in the determinant and what it represents, you might have just taken these for granted (as I did when first learning linear algebra, myself).

It goes without saying that, throughout this piece, we’ve been focussing on the intuition behind the determinant. Nothing here has been especially rigorous, and I daresay, I haven’t really ‘proven’ anything in a mathematical sense. We have kept things relatively simply by thinking purely in two-dimensional terms (though the same intuition works in higher dimensions — areas of parallelograms become volumes of parallelepipeds, and so forth).

This has been deliberate. As with my previous blog, this more high-level, intuition-driven thinking has been inspired by Grant Sanderson’s video series, ‘Essence of Linear Algebra’ (which I’d highly recommend to anyone with a passing interest in mathematics, data science, or machine learning). In Sanderson’s own words:
“The goal here is not to try to teach everything, it’s that you come away with a strong intuition… and that those intuitions make any future learning that you do more fruitful…” — Grant Sanderson
